title: This Tick Bite Makes You Allergic to Red Meat
intro: The bite of the lone star tick makes people allergic to a sugar found in mammalian products, and many doctors don’t know about it.

transcript.author: Tanya Lewis
transcript.text: Hi, this is Your Health, Quickly, a Scientific American podcast series!

transcript.author: Josh Fischman:
transcript.text: We highlight the latest vital health news: Discoveries that affect your body and your mind.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: And we break down the medical research to help you stay healthy. I’m Tanya Lewis.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: I’m Josh Fischman.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: We’re Scientific American’s senior health editors.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: On today’s show, we’re talking about ticks—and the nasty diseases these little blood-sucking vampires carry with them. One of them even makes you allergic to red meat and dairy! [Clip: Show theme music]

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: I am terrified of ticks. I like to go hiking in the Hudson Valley, but I always try to wear long pants or use insect repellant. And I check for ticks when I come home.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: You’re really actually sort of like shaking terrified of ticks? Why?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Well, I mean I especially worry about deer ticks because they carry Lyme disease. Those ticks are super common here in the Northeast. What about you, Josh?

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Funny, I actually went to college not that far from Lyme, Connecticut where that disease got its name, and I wasn’t that worried about it then. But now I’ve got this dog with this dense, black fur.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Oh, you mean Kayla?

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Yep, good old Kayla. And it’s very hard to see ticks in her fur because they’re the same color. I once was brushing Kayla and I brushed one onto myself and I didn’t see it for hours. Fortunately, it didn’t bite me. It was just hanging out, dangling from my leg.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: I’m glad it didn’t bite you, because ticks are more than just a nuisance—they transmit serious and sometimes deadly diseases. Lyme disease, for example, is probably the one we’re most familiar with, and it’s the most common vectorborne disease in the U.S.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Vectorborne means what exactly?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Any disease spread by insects that bite or suck our blood, like ticks, mosquitoes or fleas. Lyme disease is primarily caused by a bacterium called Borrelia burgdorferi, which is transmitted by the bite of the blacklegged tick—more commonly known as the deer tick. This often results in a characteristic bull’s eye rash, as well as flu-like symptoms like fever, headache, fatigue, and sometimes joint pain.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Some people experience long-term chronic symptoms too, and those can include extreme fatigue or neurological issues.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Yeah that’s pretty awful. We actually know quite a lot about Lyme disease. Or at least more than other kinds of diseases spread by ticks. But today I want to talk about a different tickborne condition, which causes a particularly bizarre problem: an allergy to red meat, among other things. It’s called alpha-gal syndrome. The tick bite causes an immune response to a sugar called galactose-α-1,3-galactose.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Okay Tanya, you get the hard science word of the week.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: I thought you’d like that. The sugar, called alpha-gal for short, is present in most mammals  except for humans and a few ape and monkey species.

transcript.author: Kersh
transcript.text: Alpha-gal syndrome is a tick-bite-associated allergic condition. We think people, after getting a tick bite, in the few weeks or maybe a couple of months after, they start having allergic reactions when they consume red meat or other products that contain the alpha-gal sugar.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: That’s Gilbert Kersh, chief of the Rickettsial Zoonoses Branch at the CDC’s Division of Vector-Borne Diseases. How’s that for a title? I talked to him a couple weeks ago for a story about alpha-gal syndrome. He co-authored a couple of recent CDC reports about how widespread this condition is and what doctors know about it.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: I’d never heard about this. A tick bite can make you allergic to hamburgers?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Yeah, strange as that may seem. Something that makes people eat less red meat might not sound so bad for the planet. But it’s actually quite severe.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: What kind of symptoms do people get?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: They are really debilitating. The reactions include gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea and vomiting.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: And it’s not just beef, right?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Right—many mammalian products contain alpha-gal, like pork…

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Bacon? Sausages?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Yup.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Venison?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Yup.

transcript.author: Fishman
transcript.text: Cheddar cheese? Regular milk?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Yeah, dairy too. It’s even in gelatin!

transcript.author: Fishman
transcript.text: So people with the syndrome could react to jello! And also, and maybe more importantly, pills like gel caps, which are made from gelatin.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Yeah, that’s the tricky part. It’s not like you can just stop eating red meat and you’ll be fine. It’s actually really hard to avoid all products that contain alpha-gal. The allergy can cause symptoms outside the digestive system, too.

transcript.author: Gilbert Kersh:
transcript.text: There are other patients who have more traditional allergic reactions—who will have hives—and some develop anaphylaxis. They may have trouble breathing, swelling of the tongue, those kinds of symptoms—which can be quite serious and often result in visits to the emergency department.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: So, what kind of tick should we look out for? And where are they?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: It’s spread by the bite of the lone star tick, which is found in the U.S. South, Midwest and mid-Atlantic. The county with the most positive tests for alpha-gal syndrome is actually Suffolk County, on Long Island.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: So, that’s close to you New York City people.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: It is. But it’s not clear if there are really more cases here, or if there’s just more awareness of the condition.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Is there any guesstimate about how many people actually have this allergy?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: According to a recent study by Kersh and his colleagues, there were more than 110,000 people in the U.S. who tested positive for alpha-gal antibodies from 2010 to 2022. But he thinks the actual number of cases is likely much higher.

transcript.author: Kersh
transcript.text: Lack of awareness among health care providers, we suspect that that 110,000 is quite a bit undercounting, and we estimate as many as 450,000 people may be living with alpha-gal syndrome in the U.S. The number of positive tests has been going up year by year.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: He mentioned lack of awareness. Do doctors really not know about this?

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Some definitely don’t. For a separate study, Kersh and his colleagues surveyed health care providers about their knowledge of alpha-gal syndrome and how to treat it.

transcript.author: Kersh
transcript.text: We did a survey of health care providers, and 42 percent of healthcare providers had not heard of alpha-gal. An additional 35 percent were not too confident in their ability to diagnose or manage a patient who had it.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: Huh, so I’m not the only one just learning about this. It’s kind of new and mysterious to the people who I’d go to for a diagnosis.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Yeah it is. And there’s no treatment. All you can do is avoid foods or medicines that contain alpha-gal. But some people experience fewer symptoms as time goes on.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: The best thing, I guess, is to avoid getting bitten by a tick in the first place.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Well, yes, that’s always the best strategy. So make sure to wear that DEET, and make sure to remove any ticks if you do find them!

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: If you get bitten by a tick, the first thing to do is to remove the entire tick, using tweezers. And if you’ve had a possible tick bite, or experience a rash or unusual symptoms, you should see your doctor.

transcript.author: Lewis
transcript.text: Definitely. But given how widespread alpha-gal syndrome already is, getting doctors to recognize it is the next step.

transcript.author: Kersh
transcript.text: One of our objectives is to increase awareness about Alpha-gal syndrome, both among the public and among healthcare providers, so that this can be recognized and managed appropriately.

transcript.author: Fischman
transcript.text: It is just another reminder that if we ignore tickborne diseases, our ignorance may come back to bite us! [CLIP: Show music]

transcript.author: Fischman
